LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Mongolia 
   
The Proposal  Support  to  the  Government  of  Mongolia  for  the  Financial 
Regulation and Governance Program (FRGP) through a program 
loan  of  SDR6,917,000  ($10  million  equivalent),  and  technical 
assistance (TA) of $900,000 for Capacity Building for Financial 
Sector Reforms. 
   
Classification  Targeting Classification: General intervention 
Sector: Finance  
Subsector: Finance sector development 
Themes: Governance, sustainable economic growth 
Subthemes:  Promoting  macroeconomic  stability,  promoting 
economic efficiency and enabling markets, financial and economic 
governance

Rationale  A  resilient  and  broad-based  financial  sector  that  effectively 
mobilizes and allocates resources is essential to create jobs and 
reduce  poverty.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  has 
supported the development of the financial sector through loans 
and TA. The first phase of comprehensive financial reforms was 
launched in 1996 against the backdrop of a fragile banking sector 
with a number of illiquid and insolvent banks. Supported by ADB’s 
Financial Sector Program Loan (FSPL I), these reforms focused 
primarily  on  bank  restructuring  and  resolution,  strengthening 
prudential  regulations  and  supervision,  and,  more  generally, 
developing  a  market-oriented  banking  sector.  The  Second 
Financial Sector Program Loan (FSPL II) supported the upgrading 
of  management  information  system  (MIS)  in  banks,  the 
introduction of the interbank market, and the development of a 
basic legal and regulatory framework for the nonbank financial 
(NBF) sector.

ii   
  As a result of these reforms, the financial sector has stabilized 
and  strengthened  since  the  1990s’  banking  crises.  Key 
achievements  include  restructuring  and  privatization  of  state-
owned  banks,  interest  rate  liberalization,  development  of  an 
interbank market, and strengthening of the banking legislation and 
regulations. At the same time, the basic infrastructure to develop 
the  NBF  sector—including  the  securities  market,  nonbank 
financial institutions (NBFIs), insurance companies, and savings 
and credit cooperatives (SCCs)—has been put in place.  
 
  Developing a well-functioning and broad-based financial system, 
however, is a gradual process, especially in transition economies 
with limited market-based institutions and human resources. While 
bank deposits and loans have increased significantly in recent 
years,  interest  rates  remain  high  and  deposits  and  loans  are 
mostly short term. The lack of an effective collateral framework, 
including weaknesses in debt enforcement and the high cost of 
collateral  registration,  increases  the  cost  of  borrowing.  Weak 
corporate governance in banks and the lack of an effective anti-
money-laundering (AML) system undermine depositor protection.  
 
  The NBF sector’s development has been hampered by legal and 
regulatory  weaknesses,  inefficient  regulatory  structure,  policy 
distortions, and low investor confidence. While SCCs have grown 
rapidly in recent years, many are believed to be engaged in risky 
and unsustainable activities. Financial services provided by NBFIs 
are largely limited to short-term consumer loans. The range of 
insurance products is narrow and the payout ratio (claims paid as 
a percentage of total premiums) is low. Progress in developing the 
capital market has been limited.  
 
  The  Government’s  Action  Plan  for  2004–2008  highlights  the 
financial sector’s role in ensuring a growth rate of about 6% over 
the medium term. The plan therefore emphasizes the importance 
of  continued  reforms  to  develop  a  stable  and  broad-based 
financial sector. Specifically, it sets out to (i) consolidate financial 
sector stabilization, (ii) strengthen the stock exchange to mobilize 
savings for productive investments, and (iii) develop a broader 
range of financial services and instruments. 
 
  The country strategy and program (CSP) for Mongolia identifies 
the underdevelopment of the financial sector and limited access of 
households and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to 
financial  services  as  key  impediments  to  private  sector-led 
economic growth and poverty reduction. A sound financial system 
with  improved  efficiency  and  outreach  is  a  key  medium-term 
outcome envisioned in the CSP.

iii
  Building on the progress achieved under the FSPL I and II, the 
FRGP aims to help develop a sound and broad-based financial 
sector, through a holistic approach to address the remaining legal 
and regulatory, institutional, and policy constraints. A broad-based 
financial  system  comprising  banks,  NBFIs,  SCCs,  securities 
markets, and the insurance sector reduces the risks associated 
with  over-reliance  on  the  banking  system,  and  increases  the 
supply of long-term capital for productive investment. It will, in 
turn, promote growth and create jobs. Increased competition from 
alternative  sources  of  financial  intermediation  will  enhance 
efficiency, and the financial system as a whole will become more 
resilient to exogenous shocks. 
 
  The reforms proposed under the FRGP are fully in line with the 
Government’s  priorities  and  medium-term  objectives.  Program 
design has benefited from the lessons learned from the FSPL I 
and II, and Mongolia’s recent strong economic performance is 
conducive to the implementation of the proposed reforms. 
   
Objectives  The FRGP’s objective is to help develop a sound and broad-
based  financial  sector  that  effectively  channels  resources  to 
productive investment projects. Specifically, the FRGP will seek to 
(i) reduce the cost of borrowing and expand access to credit by 
improving  the  collateral  framework,  (ii)  improve  governance  in 
banks to protect depositors, (iii) enhance the role of the NBF 
sector  in  mobilizing  savings  for  investment  capital,  and  (iv) 
improve investor confidence by reducing the risks from money 
laundering through the financial system. The FRGP is designed 
as a continuation of the FSPL II, and will build on the progress 
achieved under the FSPL I and II.  
 
  The FRGP’s banking sector reforms will aim to reduce the cost of 
borrowing  and  expand  access  to  credit  by  facilitating  debt 
recovery  by  banks  and  by  lowering  the  cost  of  collateral 
registration. This component will introduce legal and regulatory 
changes  to  strengthen  corporate  governance  in  banks  and  to 
improve the supervision of groups and conglomerates that control 
financial institutions. The NBF reforms will seek to enhance the 
sector’s role in mobilizing and allocating resources by developing 
the  legal  and  regulatory  framework;  strengthening  regulatory 
capacity by establishing a single regulator for the NBF sector—the 
Nonbank  Financial  Regulatory  Commission  (NBFRC);  and 
strengthening corporate governance and investor protection. This 
component will also aim to reduce the distortionary impact of tax 
policies on the financial sector. The AML component will seek to 
mitigate the risks from money laundering by developing the legal 
and  regulatory  framework,  and  by  establishing  a  financial 
intelligence unit (FIU) in the Bank of Mongolia (BOM).

iv   
Loan Amount and Terms  It is proposed that ADB support the Government’s policy reforms 
under the FRGP by providing a loan of SDR6,917,000 ($10 million 
equivalent). The Borrower will be Mongolia. The loan will be from 
the ADB’s Special Funds resources. The loan will have a term of 
24 years, including a grace period of 8 years, and an interest 
charge of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per 
year for the remaining period. The loan proceeds are expected to 
be used over 48 months from the date of effectiveness. 
   
Program Period and  The program period will be 4 years. The loan will be released in 
Tranching  two  equal  tranches.  The  first,  SDR3,458,500  ($5  million 
equivalent), will be released upon loan effectiveness. The second, 
SDR3,458,500 ($5 million equivalent), will be released 24 months 
after  Board  approval,  subject  to  the  Government  meeting  the 
conditions specified for its release. 
   
Executing and  The Ministry of Finance (MOF) will be the Executing Agency for 
Implementing Agencies  the loan. BOM will be the Implementing Agency for the banking 
sector and AML components. NBFRC will be the Implementing 
Agency for the NBF sector component.  
   
Procurement  The loan proceeds will be used to finance the foreign exchange 
cost of items produced and procured in ADB member countries 
(other than the items specified in the list of ineligible items and 
imports financed by other bilateral and multilateral sources). The 
Government will certify that the volume of eligible imports exceeds 
the amount of ADB’s projected disbursement under the loan for 
the period. ADB reserves the right to audit the use of the loan 
proceeds  and  verify  the  accuracy  of  the  Government’s 
certification. 
   
Counterpart Funds  The  Government  will  ensure  that  the  local  currency  funds 
generated by the program loan will be used, first, to support the 
adjustment  cost  of  reforms  under  the  FRGP,  and  second,  to 
finance  expenditures  for  general  development  purposes  of 
Mongolia. 
   
Risks and Safeguards  Poor management of the transition to NBFRC is a key risk. A 
number of measures have been taken to facilitate a timely and 
orderly transition. An overall strategy and a detailed time-bound 
action plan have been prepared in close consultation with the 
Government  and  other  key  stakeholders.  During  program 
preparation, considerable efforts were made to reach a common 
understanding  and  consensus  among  different  government 
agencies on the objectives and structure of NBFRC. BOM has 
committed to transfer at least eight qualified staff members to 
NBFRC, and the Government has agreed to allocate budget to 
ensure an adequate pool of qualified professional staff to conduct 
regulatory, supervisory, and enforcement functions. The attached 
TA will provide policy and technical guidance and training for a 
smooth transition.

v
  Another risk is that the introduction of new legislation and legal 
amendments will be delayed significantly and/or will not fully meet 
the  program  objectives.  Inconsistencies  among  different  laws 
could create confusion and loopholes. This risk is minimized to the 
extent that many of the laws to be enacted during the FRGP were 
drafted during program preparation or under other ADB projects. 
In line with the recommendation of the program completion report 
for  the  FSPL  II,  stakeholder  consultations  were  held  during 
program preparation to ensure that the expected outcomes of the 
legal  reforms  are  fully  understood.  A  number  of  crucial  laws, 
including those related to the collateral framework, tax reforms, 
and the establishment of NBFRC, have either been enacted or 
submitted to Parliament. The attached TA will support the legal 
reforms and ensure that any revisions made by the Government 
do not undermine the laws’ effectiveness. 
 
  Resistance from vested interests to certain reforms is a potential 
risk, and is particularly relevant to the AML and tax reforms. The 
Government has expressed strong commitment to implementing 
AML reforms, and has prepared a draft AML law. Submission of 
the law to Parliament is a condition for loan effectiveness. An 
ongoing TA is helping develop implementing regulations and a 
blueprint for information technology and reporting requirements, 
and  is  providing  related  training  to  government  agencies  and 
financial institutions. This will help facilitate the implementation of 
the  FRGP’s  AML  component.  With  assistance  from  the 
International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the United States Agency 
for  International  Development  (USAID),  the  Government  has 
prepared a reform proposal to improve the efficiency of the overall 
tax system. The Corporate Income Tax Law recently submitted to 
Parliament incorporates measures to reduce tax impediments to 
NBF  development.  ADB,  IMF,  and  USAID  should  continue  to 
coordinate with each other to ensure satisfactory implementation 
of these tax reforms.

vi   
Technical Assistance  The TA’s purpose is to support the FRGP’s policy reforms, and to 
strengthen the capacities of NBFRC and the FIU. Specifically, the 
TA will help the Government (i) implement the procedures for non-
judicial  foreclosure  of  collateral;  (ii)  establish  NBFRC  by 
developing transition arrangements, organizational structure, and 
internal procedures; (iii) draft laws and regulations to address the 
weaknesses  and  gaps  in  the  legal  framework;  (iv)  introduce 
corporate governance structure and practices in banks, nonbank 
financial  intermediaries,  and  securities  issuers;  (v)  develop 
information technology-management information system (IT-MIS) 
in NBFRC and the FIU; and (vi) provide capacity-building training 
in financial regulation; on-site and off-site supervision; accounting, 
auditing, and reporting standards; and IT-MIS. The total TA cost is 
estimated at $1,120,000, of which ADB will finance $900,000 on a 
grant  basis  through  the  Japan  Special  Fund,  funded  by  the 
Government of Japan. MOF will be the Executing Agency, and 
BOM and NBFRC will be the implementing agencies. The TA will 
require  a  total  of  63  person-months’  consulting  services  (23 
person-months’  international  and  40  person-months’  national). 
The consultants will be recruited by ADB through firms, selected 
under the quality- and cost-based selection method, using the 
simplified technical proposal in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to 
ADB on the engagement of national consultants.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to Mongolia for the Financial Regulation and Governance Program (FRGP). The report also 
describes  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Capacity  Building  for  Financial  Sector 
Reforms, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to 
me by the Board, will approve the TA. 
 
 
II.  THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT  
2.  Following a sharp decline in output during the early transition period, the economy 
returned to a positive growth rate in 1994, and grew by 3.9% annually from 1994 to 1999. The 
relatively quick economic recovery reflected favorable international copper and cashmere prices 
and the efficiency gains from market-oriented reforms. Demonstrating the country’s vulnerability 
to exogenous shocks, the annual gross domestic product (GDP) growth rate dropped to 1% in 
2001 as international copper prices fell and consecutive harsh winters and an outbreak of foot 
and mouth disease led to sharp decline in agricultural output. Boosted by strong growth in 
agriculture and mining—which jointly account for 30% of GDP—the annual growth rate climbed 
from 1.0% in 2001 to 10.6% in 2004. After many years of moderation, inflation surged in the first 
half of 2005, and reached 17.5% in June 2005, reflecting large increases in oil and meat prices. 
While it declined as the impact of the food price shock was undone, inflation remains high at 
11.5%. 
   
3.  Supported by favorable terms of trade, better-than-expected gold volume, and capital 
inflows reflecting the recovery in tourism and increasing remittances, the current account shifted 
to a small surplus in 2004, from a deficit of 7.8% in 2003. The budget deficit narrowed from 
7.7%  of  GDP  in  2000  to  2%  in  2004,  reflecting  strong  growth  and  a  boom  in  minerals. 
Mongolia’s reform process has been underpinned by development aid, and the debt level 
stands at about 91% of GDP. Since most of the debt consists of loans from multilateral or 
bilateral sources on concessional terms, however, the debt level is deemed manageable.  
 
4.  The benefits of economic growth are not evenly distributed, as indicated by income 
inequality and persistent poverty; 36% of Mongolians live under the national poverty line. High 
unemployment (14.2%) and underemployment caused by a mismatch of skills stand as the main 
causes of poverty. Services are the main source of employment, followed by agriculture and 
industry. 
 
5.  The boom in mining investment is expected to continue, given the strong prospects for 
new exploration in the Gobi desert and strong demand from the People’s Republic of China. 
Growth is expected to settle at about 5% over the next 2 or 3 years, and with the appropriate 
monetary policy, inflation is forecast to slow down to about 5% in 2006. However, sustained 
growth faces a number of constraints. The narrow economic base and high dependence on 
commodity  production  and  trade  make  the  country  vulnerable  to  exogenous  shocks. 
Fragmented domestic markets and geographic isolation hinder growth. Manufacturing sector 
growth is constrained by the prevalent use of old technology and limited human resources.

2               
6.  The Government’s Action Plan for 2004–2008 highlights the importance of continued 
financial  sector  reforms  in  ensuring  a  growth  rate  of  about  6%  over  the  medium  term.1  
Accordingly, the plan sets out to (i) consolidate financial sector stabilization, (ii) strengthen the 
stock exchange to mobilize savings for productive investments, and (iii) develop a broader 
range of financial services and instruments.  
 
7.  The  country  strategy  and  program  (CSP)2  for  Mongolia  identifies  financial 
underdevelopment as a main constraint on private sector-led economic growth and poverty 
reduction. The banking sector has stabilized and strengthened since the 1990s’ crises, and the 
Government has started to build the basic foundation for the nonbank financial (NBF) sector. 
However, the financial sector’s role in promoting economic growth has been limited. The cost of 
borrowing is high and financial outreach limited. The lack of long-term funding sources limits 
productive investment. There are few savings instruments and insurance products. A sound 
financial  system  with  improved  efficiency  and  outreach  is  a  key  medium-term  outcome 
envisioned in the CSP. 
 
 
III.  THE SECTOR: PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES  
A.  Sector Description and Performance3  
8.  The financial sector comprises the banking sector, and the NBF sector, which includes 
nonbank  financial  institutions  (NBFIs),  savings  and  credit  cooperatives  (SCCs),  securities 
markets and intermediaries, and insurance companies. The banking sector has grown rapidly in 
recent years, and bank deposits and assets as percentage of GDP are the highest in the region 
(Table 1). However, at 11.2%, the interest rate spread is high, and nonperforming loans (NPLs) 
have increased since 2001. While the NBF sector has grown in recent years, it is significantly 
smaller  than  the  banking  sector,  and  does  not  yet  play  a  meaningful  role  in  financial 
intermediation. The excessive reliance on the banking sector makes the economy vulnerable to 
shocks.

1.  Banking Sector 
9.  The banking sector has strengthened considerably since the 1990s’ crises. With total 
assets of MNT1.1 trillion or 61% of GDP, the banking system dominates the financial sector. Of 
the 17 commercial banks, 1 is state-owned (Savings Bank), and 4 have foreign ownership.4 
Except for one Russian bank branch, no foreign banks are licensed to operate in Mongolia. The 
banking sector is highly concentrated, with the four largest banks accounting for 61% of total 
banking assets, and 69% of deposits. In 2006, the Bank of Mongolia (BOM) will increase 
minimum capital requirements of banks from the current MNT4 billion to MNT8 billion. This is 
expected  to  drive  consolidation  within  the  sector  as  only  three  banks  have  capital  levels 
exceeding MNT8 billion. 
 
10.  Deposits and loans as a share of GDP grew from 14% and 8% in 1999 to 39% and 35% 
in 2004. Bank deposits and loans are mostly short-term, with maturities of less than 1 year. 
While interest rates are trending down, they remain high. The deposit and lending rates of 
banks were about 14% and 25% in 2004. High interest spreads are symptomatic of high credit 
risk, high operating costs of banks, strong demand for bank loans because of a lack of other 
funding sources, and lack of effective competition among banks. 
 
11.  The ratio of total capital to assets of the banking sector increased from below 4% in 
1998 to 15% in 2004, and the entire banking sector has been profitable for the past 5 years 
(2000–2004). The NPL ratio declined from 54% in 1999 to 8% in 2001 and then stayed at 7–
11% until 2004. The loan loss reserves are provisioned in line with the BOM guidelines, and 
stand at a high level. While the rapid increase in bank loans during 2001–2003 raised concerns, 
credit expansion slowed down in 2004. Credit expanded by 88% annually during 2001–2003 
and grew by 44% in 2004. However, the NPL ratio increased from 7% in 2002 to 8% in 2003 
and to 11% in 2004, reflecting poor performance of the loans recently extended and weak 
internal control and risk assessment capacities in banks.  
 
2.  Nonbank Financial Institutions  
12.  The term NBFI refers to a licensee under the Law on Nonbank Financial Activities 
(2002).  The  activities  covered  under  this  law  include  lending,  factoring,  leasing,  issuing 
guarantees, issuing payment instruments, electronic payments and remittance services, foreign 
exchange services, trust services, investment in short-term financial instruments, and advisory 
services. Each NBFI is licensed for one or more activities, but there is no overall license to be 
an NBFI. NBFIs are not allowed to take deposits. While most of the smaller NBFIs are financed 
by equity, some large ones have significant loan financing and accrued interests. 
 
13.  The number, loans, and total assets of NBFIs have grown rapidly since 2000, when 
Mongol Credit was established as the first licensed NBFI. Of the 114 NBFIs registered in 2004, 
9 were foreign-owned or joint ventures. Most NBFIs provide small consumer loans, or short-
term loans to small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), and a handful are engaged in other 
activities such as leasing and foreign exchange trading. NBFIs are incorporated as limited 
liability companies, and are typically owned by an individual, a family, or a small group of related 
individuals. With total assets of MNT28.7 billion, NBFIs as a group account for about 2.6% of 
banking sector assets. NBFIs’ NPLs are 4.5% of total loans.

3.  Savings and Credit Cooperatives  
14.  SCCs are established under the Law on Cooperatives to provide saving and lending 
services to members. While SCCs have to register with the General Department of National 
Taxation (GDNT), they are not required to obtain a license from a financial regulator. The 
number of SCCs has dramatically increased in the last several years. The joint survey by BOM 
and GDNT during the first quarter of 2004 showed that there are 570 registered SCCs, of which 
288 are believed to be inactive or bankrupt, or could not be located by the authorities. SCC 
assets amount to MNT47.1 billion, about 6% of total banking sector assets. SCC activities are 
concentrated in Ulaanbaatar, which has 166 SCCs with total assets of MNT44.6 billion. The 
sector is highly concentrated, with the 14 largest SCCs accounting for 76.2% of total assets. 
Although SCCs are allowed to take deposits only from the members, many SCCs take deposits 
from the public. 
 
4.  Securities Market and Intermediaries 
15.  There  are  395  companies  listed  on  the  Mongolian  Stock  Exchange  (MSE).  Market 
capitalization  in  2004  was  MNT29.8  billion  (1.4%  of  GDP)  and  annual  trading  value  was 
MNT654 million. The trading value at MSE has been declining since a large part of corporate 
shares have been traded outside MSE and concentrated in small number of shareholders. In 
2004, only 1,300 companies and individuals owned 96% of the shares of all listed companies. 
Private companies and financial institutions currently do not use MSE to raise new equity 
capital.  Total  trade  value  of  bonds  in  2004  was  MNT15.3  billion,  of  which  81.8%  were 
government bonds and 18.2% corporate bonds. Nearly all the government and corporate bonds 
are bought by banks and held to maturity, and there is virtually no secondary market trading. As 
a result of rapid decline in trading activity and the increase in minimum capital requirement (from 
MNT10  million  to  MNT50  million  in  January  2003),  the  number  of  licensed  securities 
broker/dealer  companies  declined  from  42  in  2000  to  25  in  2004.  Of  the  25  securities 
companies, 2 have foreign participation. There is no licensed underwriter and no collective 
investment funds.  
 
16.  In 2003, MSE was divided into two separate legal entities: MSE and the Securities 
Clearing House and Central Depository. The separation of trading and listing functions of MSE 
from  its  securities  clearing  and  depository  systems  aimed  to  improve  transparency  and 
accountability. MSE is organized as a government-owned profit-making joint stock company. 
MSE shares were listed on the stock exchange in 2003 but are not traded since MSE is 100% 
Government-owned. MSE continues to operate as a traditional state-owned enterprise (SOE) 
with six government representatives on the board, including the Mongolian Securities Exchange 
Commission (MSEC), and only one private sector representative from a broker/dealer company. 
 
5.  Insurance Industry 
17.  The number of insurance companies increased from 10 to 23 from 1999 to March 2005. 
Following the privatization of the largest insurance company, Mongol Daatgal, in February 2004, 
all insurance companies are now privately owned. In 2003, total insurance premiums were 
MNT6.3 billion, about 0.5% of GDP. Aircraft-related insurance (hull and liability) comprises the 
largest category and accounts for 40% of the industry. The only class of mandatory insurance is 
motor  vehicle  liability,  accounting  for  8%  of  total  industry  premium.  The  sector  is  highly 
concentrated, with Mongol Daatgal accounting for 74% of total insurance sector premiums in 
2003. The recent bankruptcies of two insurance companies have raised concerns about the

5 
solvency of the smaller companies. The insurance payout ratio (claims paid as a percentage of 
total premiums collected) is low at 20%. 
 
B.  Issues and Opportunities 
 
1.  Banking Sector 
a.  Lack of an Effective Collateral Framework 
18.  The  absence  of  an  effective  collateral  framework  is  a  key  impediment  to  financial 
intermediation. The Second Financial Sector Program Loan (FSPL II)5 supported measures to 
expand the types of collateral that banks can accept from immovable to movable property and 
financial assets, and to reduce the cost of collateral registration. Under the FSPL II, the Civil 
Code was amended to allow banks to seize immovable property without a court decision. 
However, the 2002 Civil Code includes another article that contradicts the previous one. This is 
a major setback for banks and removes a strong incentive for borrowers to meet their debt 
obligations.  The  court  procedures  for  securing  and  enforcing  collateral  are  lengthy  and 
cumbersome. After the court decision, the Court Decision Enforcement Office (bailiff’s office) 
takes months and even years from the court decision to the actual foreclosure, and charges 
fees as high as 10% of the property’s value. The information available from the Property 
Registration Office (PRO) in the Ministry of Construction and Urban Development (MOC) is 
limited,  making  it  difficult  for  banks  to  assess  the  creditworthiness  of  potential  borrowers. 
Combined, these factors weaken banks’ leverage in foreclosure and increase credit risk, adding 
significantly to the interest premiums charged by banks. The high cost of notarizing documents 
for  collateral  registration—which  can  be  up  to  MNT40,000—also  increases  the  cost  of 
borrowing.  
 
b.  Weak Governance and Depositor Protection 
19.  While  corporate  governance  practices  have  improved  in  recent  years,  they  vary 
considerably across the 17 commercial banks. In particular, the three banks that have foreign 
management or long-term international advisors—Agricultural Bank, Trade and Development 
Bank, and Xac Bank—have developed sound corporate governance structures. However, some 
banks are believed to engage in substantial related-party lending at below-market rates and 
without consideration of creditworthiness.  
 
20.  Weak Internal Controls. Related-party lending is largely due to the weak system of 
checks and balances. The Banking Law requires that banks’ board of directors be shareholders. 
By preventing the appointment of independent directors, this requirement impedes the effective 
functioning of banks’ governing boards and auditing committees. Most of the banks are closely 
held limited liability companies with one or two shareholders controlling the majority of shares, 
and a representative of the majority shareholder chairing the governing board. The corporate 
governance guidelines issued by BOM in 2002 do not include clearly specified fiduciary duties 
and  safeguards  against  related-party  transactions,  and  functions  of  board  committees. 
Addressing these gaps will help promote transparency and prevent conflict of interest and fraud, 
thereby protecting depositors.

21.  Weak Supervision of Financial Groups and Conglomerates. Mongolian banks are 
prohibited from holding nonbank financial intermediaries and other companies as subsidiaries. 
However, banks may be owned or controlled by one or more financial or non-financial firms. 
There are few limitations on the activities, including financial ones, of banks’ shareholders and 
their affiliates, and financial supervisors have limited information about the groups of enterprises 
that hold banks and other financial institutions. As a result, despite the strict limitations on 
banks’ business activities and shareholding, the potential risks arising from financial and other 
activities of banks’ shareholders and their affiliates are not properly monitored and managed by 
BOM. Anecdotal evidence suggests that many banks are funding the activities of their owners 
and  affiliates  of  the  owners.  These  concerns  highlight  the  immediate  need  to  improve 
supervision of financial groups and conglomerates to protect depositors. 
  
2.  Nonbank Financial Sector 
a.  Fragmented Regulatory Structure and Weak Institutional Capacity 
22.  NBF regulation is fragmented and weak. Regulatory and supervisory responsibilities are 
divided  among  BOM,  which  is  responsible  for  regulating  NBFIs  and  SCCs  in  addition  to 
commercial banks; the Insurance Supervisory Unit (ISU) of the State Agency for Professional 
Inspectors; and MSEC.  
 
23.  Having several regulators is costly and inefficient, especially in a small country like 
Mongolia. Of the 50 or so staff members in BOM’s Supervision Department, 10 are in charge of 
NBFI supervision. BOM has issued prudential requirements for SCCs, but it has neither the 
legal authority nor the staff resources to supervise SCCs. Therefore, BOM does not have staff 
members responsible for monitoring SCCs’ compliance with prudential regulations. As rapidly 
growing deposit-taking institutions, SCCs must be adequately supervised. MSEC has only 20 
staff members. It does not have a specialized unit for enforcement, which is one of the most 
important  responsibilities  of  a  securities  regulator.  The  FSPL  II  supported  institutional 
strengthening  of  MSEC  through  investment  in  computer  information  systems  and  through 
domestic and international training. However, lack of resources to recruit specialized experts 
such as a chief accountant and a chief legal and enforcement officer, as would be possible in a 
larger  financial  regulatory  body,  has  hampered  MSEC’s  ability  to  effectively  regulate  the 
securities market. The ISU employs only seven staff members, none with adequate specialized 
expertise  in  insurance.  Establishing  a  regulatory  structure  that  is  more  efficient  and  cost-
effective is crucial for enhancing NBF regulation and supervision. 
 
24.  MSE  was  launched  in  February  1992  to  implement  the  Government’s  privatization 
program. Asian Development Bank (ADB) assistance was instrumental in providing policy and 
technical advice, and in financing basic computer equipment early on. However, MSE continues 
to be perceived mainly as a venue for SOE privatization, and further institutional strengthening 
is needed to transform MSE into a modern stock exchange where private companies and 
financial  institutions  can  raise  long-term  capital.  Further  strengthening  of  the  legal  and 
regulatory framework is also crucial for capital market development. 
 
b.  Gaps and Anomalies in the Legal Framework  
25.  The NBF sector is governed mainly by the Law on Nonbank Financial Activities (2002), 
Law  on  Cooperatives  (1998,  amended  2002),  Law  on  Insurance  (1998),  and  the  Law  on

7 
Securities Market (2002).6 They vary considerably in their legal bases for effective regulation 
and supervision. Under the current framework, the ISU is not authorized to license and regulate 
insurance companies: licensing and regulatory powers still reside with the Ministry of Finance 
(MOF).  This  arrangement  not  only  undermines  the  ISU’s  role  but  also  significantly  delays 
licensing.  The  Laws  on  Insurance  and  Law  on  Licensing  and  Supervision  of  Insurance 
Intermediaries, prepared with ADB support,7 have strengthened the licensing and prudential 
requirements and provide for a single agency to license, regulate, and supervise insurance 
intermediaries. However, the law has not yet entered into force, and implementing regulations 
have not been finalized and issued. 
 
26.  The 2002 amendments to the Law on Cooperatives provide for prudential regulation of 
SCC by BOM. However, the law does not provide adequate basis for effective regulation and 
supervision of SCC activities. In particular, it does not require that SCCs be licensed by a 
designated entity, does not confer adequate supervisory powers on BOM, and does not provide 
for the suspension or revocation of the registration of a cooperative that has breached the law.  
 
27.  A fundamental weakness of the Law on Securities Market is that it does not clearly 
distinguish between the provisions that apply to public offers, and those to private offers of 
securities. The law is not sufficiently clear on whether joint stock companies are required to be 
listed.  One  consequence  of  this  is  that  companies  that  do  not  meet  the  governance  and 
disclosure requirements continue to be listed on MSE. The ability of a joint stock company to 
unlist  would  enable  MSEC  to  de-list  a  joint  stock  company  that  no  longer  meets  listing 
requirements  without  necessarily  requiring  that  the  company  convert  into  a  limited  liability 
company. While the law recognizes the creation and operation of investment funds, it is weak 
on the segregation and protection of fund assets and the obligations of the governing persons of 
investment funds and funds management companies. “Fit and proper” standards for directors of 
governing  boards,  senior  managers,  and  major  shareholders  of  securities  issuers  and 
professional participants are not required under the law. Moreover, the law does not make it an 
offense  for  an  individual  or  a  legal  entity  to  conduct  the  business  of  a  securities  market 
intermediary without obtaining license from MSEC.8  
 
28.  An effective financial regulatory regime must make appropriate use of self-regulatory 
organizations (SROs) to exercise some direct oversight responsibility over its members, in 
addition  to  the  oversight  by  the  government  regulator.  For  instance,  the  broker/dealer 
association could be assigned the responsibility of monitoring the activities of its member and 
taking disciplinary actions if necessary. The lack of such power under the law prevents MSEC 
from authorizing an industry body such as MSE or the Securities Dealer Association to take on 
SRO functions.  
  
c.  Weak Governance, Disclosure, and Investor Confidence

governance  and  stakeholder  protection.  It  provides  the  basis  for  regulating  the  formation, 
registration,  and  governance  of  limited  liability  companies  and  joint  stock  companies.  The 
governance  requirements  for  limited  liability  companies  under  this  law  are  minimal.  For

30.  To  promote  internationally  recognized  standards  of  accounting,  the  Government 
promulgated the Accounting Law in 1993 (amended in 2001), requiring business enterprises to 
adopt  international  accounting  standards.  The  law  also  required  the  establishment  of  the

Mongolia Institute of Certified Public Accountants in 1996. The Audit Law (1997) requires the

31.  The range of monetary penalties that may be imposed on individuals and legal entities 
that violate the relevant laws is evidently not adequate to act as a deterrent. For example, the 
penalty prescribed for violation of the Law on Securities Market is MNT20,000–40,000 for 
individuals, and MNT100,000–200,000 for legal entities. A fine of MNT40,000 represents just a 
quarter more than the minimum monthly wage in Mongolia, which stands at about MNT30,000. 
In contrast, the Law on Nonbank Financial Activities allows for a much higher range of fines: 5–
20 times the minimum wage for individuals and 20–40 times for NBFIs.  
   
d.  Tax Impediments 
32.  Distortions created by the tax system have also constrained the NBF sector. A key 
distortion arises from the corporate tax system. Mongolia levies a progressive rate, whereby the 
tax rate is 15% for companies with profits less than MNT100 million and 30% for companies 
with  higher  profits.  This  has  had  significant  adverse  effects.  First,  it  penalizes  efficient 
companies with high profits. Second, the tax system encourages companies to split into smaller 
companies to avoid paying the higher rate. Besides not being able to benefit from economies of 
scale,  the  smaller  companies  are  not  able  to  raise  funds  through  the  capital  market.  By 
encouraging the creation of subsidiaries, the corporate income tax system also complicates 
management structures, resulting in inefficiency and lack of transparency.  
 
33.  The differential tax treatment on the returns of different types of financial assets is 
another distortion. Interest on government debt is tax exempt. According to the Corporate 
Income Tax (CIT) Law and Personal Income Tax (PIT) Law, interest income on bank deposits is 
subject to a 15% tax rate. However, this article will come into effect only in 2008. Therefore, 
interest on bank deposits is currently tax exempt. However, dividends are subject to a 15% tax 
rate, and capital gains on equity investment to up to 30%, discouraging investment in the equity 
market. In most countries, one reason why founders of closely held limited liability companies 
list on the stock exchange is to realize a capital gain as share prices increase. Further, reserves 
for  expected  losses  are  tax  deductible  for  commercial  banks  and SCCs  but  not  for  other 
financial institutions. Harmonizing the taxation of banking and NBF sectors is crucial to develop 
a broad-based financial sector.

3.  Need for an Effective Anti-Money-Laundering Regime 
34.  Money laundering has its origins in graft, corruption, and other criminal activities. The 
perceived risks from money laundering through the financial system can significantly erode 
depositor confidence.9 Mongolia has recently received large capital inflows, the sources of 
which are not properly traced and tracked. The lack of transparency and information leads to 
gaps  in  the  financial  system  through  which  illegal  funds  could  flow,  which  could,  in  turn, 
undermine financial soundness and stability. Mongolia’s location makes it particularly vulnerable 
to illegal funds being routed through the country to hide their origin and destination.  
 
35.  The development of an effective anti-money-laundering (AML) regime is fundamental to 
strengthening the financial sector and its governance. Proper controls for money laundering will, 
in turn, reduce the scope for other types of crime such as drug trafficking and corruption. The 
Government has taken the initial steps to address the potential risks from money laundering. A 
government  resolution  issued  in  2001  instructs  MOF  to  cooperate  with  international 
organizations in combating terrorist financing and money laundering.  The Government has 
prepared a draft AML law, which is being finalized for submission to Parliament. Adopting the 
legal framework, however, is only the first step. To establish a fully effective AML system, 
implementing rules and regulations need to be developed, and the institutional arrangement and 
information technology (IT) equipment to report and prosecute money laundering put in place.  
 
C.  Government Strategy 
36.  Despite  a  difficult  transition  period  marked  by  financial  turbulence  and  economic 
instability, the Government has been committed to substantive financial reform. Government 
ownership of previous ADB projects has been strong. In 2003, the Government finalized a 
national poverty reduction strategy in the form of the Economic Growth Support and Poverty 
Reduction Strategy, from which the new Government derived a new law outlining the National 
Action Plan for 2004–2008. The plan highlights the role of the financial sector in ensuring a 
growth rate of about 6% over the medium term. The plan also highlights the importance of 
continued reforms to develop a stable and broad-based financial sector. Specifically, the plan 
sets out to (i) consolidate financial sector stabilization; (ii) strengthen the stock exchange to 
mobilize savings for productive investments; and (iii) develop a broader range of financial 
services and instruments.10 The Government has strongly endorsed the FRGP, which is fully in 
line with its priorities and medium-term objectives.  
 
D.  ADB Operations and Lessons Learned 
37.  Financial sector development has been a key focus of ADB’s operations in Mongolia. 
The country operational strategies of 1991 and 1994 expressed general support for the sector, 
recommending assistance in policy and regulatory reform. The 2000 strategy recommended 
that ADB assistance focus on banking sector reforms, followed by a second phase (starting 
2003) of broadening assistance to establish the necessary financial infrastructure beyond the 
banking sector. The 2000 strategy also proposed credit lines for targeted on-lending to SMEs 
and rural enterprises, and for low-income housing.

38.  Provision of TA started as early as 1991, when ADB supported MSE’s establishment to 
facilitate  the  Government’s  privatization  program.  Subsequent  TA  has  supported  bank 
restructuring and privatization, capacity building of BOM, capacity building of accounting and 
auditing professionals, development of securities market law and regulations, establishment of 
MSEC, and drafting of AML law and regulations. 
 
39.  Responding  to  the  emerging  needs  of  the  financial  sector,  ADB  has  provided  two 
program loans to Mongolia. The first phase of comprehensive financial reforms was launched in 
1996 against the backdrop of a fragile banking sector with a number of illiquid and insolvent 
banks. Supported by ADB’s Financial Sector Program Loan (FSPL I),11 these reforms focused 
primarily on bank restructuring and resolution,12 strengthening prudential regulations and on-site 
and off-site supervision, and more generally encouraging the market orientation of the banking 
sector. The TA loan13 provided in conjunction with the FSPL I supported the upgrading of the 
information technology-management information system (IT-MIS) in commercial banks, and the 
establishment of the Bank Training Center (BTC). However, initial improvements in the sector 
were short-lived, in part because of delays in bank restructuring and in part because of the 
onset of the Asian and Russian financial crises in the second half of the 1990s. The effects of 
the  Asian  crisis,  in  particular,  resulted  in  a  fall  in  international  prices  of  major  export 
commodities, including copper, gold, and cashmere, placing pressure on loan servicing by 
exporters and further eroding the quality of bank assets.  
 
40.  In 1999, the Government formulated the second phase financial sector reform strategy, 
which was implemented with support from the FSPL II14 and the World Bank’s Financial Sector 
Adjustment  Credit  (FSAC).  FSAC  supported  the  restructuring  of  the  Savings  Bank  and 
Agriculture  Bank,  the  strengthening  of  banking  regulations,  and  the  strengthening  of  the 
Mongolian  Asset  Recovery  Agency  and  the  credit  information  bureau.  The  FSPL  II 
complemented FSAC by developing guidelines for corporate governance in banks, improving 
the collateral framework by expanding the types of assets that can be pledged and simplifying 
the  collateral  registration  process,  supporting  the  implementation  of  IT-MIS  in  commercial 
banks, and developing an interbank market. The FSPL II also included measures to strengthen 
the laws and regulations governing NBFIs and insurance companies and to promote capital 
market development by strengthening the legislation and capacity building of MSEC. 
 
41.  As  a  result  of  these  reforms,  the  financial  sector  has  stabilized  and  strengthened 
considerably  since  the  1990s’  banking  crises.  Key  achievements  include  restructuring  and 
privatization  of  state-owned  banks,  interest  rate  liberalization,  development  of  an  efficient 
interbank market, and strengthening of the legal and regulatory framework for banks, including 
regulatory capacity of BOM. IT-MIS in commercial banks has improved significantly, and BTC is 
emerging  as  an  increasingly  credible  and  self-sustaining  institution.  The  FSPL  II  was 
instrumental in laying the groundwork for further NBF sector development. However, developing 
a well-functioning and broad-based financial system is a gradual process, especially in transition 
economies  that  lack  market-based  institutions  and  human  resources.  The  remaining

42.  Building on the progress achieved under the FSPL I and II, the FRGP aims to further the 
Government’s reform efforts by using a comprehensive approach to address the remaining 
legal, regulatory, institutional and policy weaknesses highlighted above. Besides addressing 
weaknesses specific to the subsectors, the FRGP’s reform measures also take into account the 
links  and  complementarities  between  the  banking  and  NBF  sectors.  Strong  economic 
performance in recent years provides a conducive environment for financial reform. Using a 
result-based approach, further ADB assistance will be determined by outcomes of the FRGP, 
and by assessment of the financial sector’s emerging needs. 
 
43.  Lessons  learned  from  ADB’s  financial  sector  projects  in  Mongolia  were  taken  into 
account in designing the FRGP. The country assistance program evaluation provides valuable 
lessons and recommendations based on an in-depth review of ADB’s operations in Mongolia.15 
The evaluation notes that the efficacy of the FSPL I and II would have been strengthened had 
the underlying issues and priorities been analyzed in more detail during program preparation.16 
In  line  with  this  recommendation,  the  FRGP  was  prepared  with  a  comprehensive  project 
preparatory  TA  covering  legal,  regulatory,  policy,  and  institutional  impediments  to  financial

44.  A key lesson from the FSPL I is that the establishment of new institutions should be 
based  on  adequate  analysis  of  the  long-term  viability  of  the  institution,  and  that  sufficient 
capacity building should be provided to ensure that they are sustainable. The attached TA will 
provide policy and technical guidance and capacity-building training to ensure the sustainability 
of the proposed Nonbank Financial Regulatory Commission (NBFRC). The attached TA will also 
support the establishment of IT-MIS in NBFRC and in the financial intelligence unit (FIU) in 
BOM. The program performance audit report for the FSPL I17 emphasizes the urgent need to 
address the weaknesses in the secured transactions framework, and recommends that the 
adoption of legal reforms to improve the collateral framework be a precondition for any new 
ADB loan for financial sector reforms. Developing an effective collateral framework is a program 
objective. 
 
45.  An important lesson from the FSPL II is the need to focus on achieving policy objectives 
rather than technical compliance. For instance, even though the policy conditions of the FSPL II 
were technically met, some reform measures were not properly implemented and did not fully 
generate  expected  results  and  objectives.  The  adoption  of  new  laws  and  regulations  was 
delayed partly because the lack of understanding, by government officials and members of 
parliament,  of  the  intended  objectives  and  outcomes  the  policy  conditions.  The  lack  of 
understanding about the functioning of the capital market, in particular, impeded capital market 
reforms. The rationale for specific policy conditions must, therefore, be fully clarified during 
program  preparation.  To  this  end,  stakeholders—including  members  of  parliament,  and 
representatives from the Government, financial institutions, and the corporate sector—have 
been  consulted  extensively.  Policy  conditions  related  to  legal  reforms  outline  the  specific 
provisions that are required to meet the program objectives. Another key lesson from the FSPL 
II is that program implementation is just as important as program design. The effectiveness of

IV.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 
A.  Objective and Scope 
48.  The FRGP’s objective is to help develop a sound and broad-based financial sector that 
effectively channels resources into productive investment. Specifically, the FRGP will seek to (i) 
reduce the cost of borrowing and expand access to credit by improving the collateral framework, 
(ii) improve governance in banks to protect depositors, (iii) enhance the role of the NBF sector in 
savings mobilization for investment capital, and (iv) improve investor confidence by reducing the 
risks from potential money laundering through the financial system. The FRGP is designed as a 
continuation of the FSPL II, and will build on the progress achieved under the FSPL I and II. The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 3. 
 
49.  The FRGP includes critical policy reforms for financial sector development. The banking 
sector reforms under the FRGP aim to reduce the cost of borrowing and expand access to 
credit by facilitating debt recovery by banks and by lowering the cost of collateral registration.

13 
This component will introduce legal and regulatory changes to strengthen corporate governance 
in banks and to improve the supervision of groups and conglomerates that control financial 
institutions. The NBF reforms seek to enhance the sector’s role in resource mobilization and 
allocation by developing the legal and regulatory framework, strengthening regulatory capacity 
by establishing a single regulator for NBF sector—NBFRC, and by strengthening corporate 
governance and investor protection. This component also aims to reduce the distortionary 
impact of tax policies on the financial sector. The AML component seeks to mitigate the risks 
from money laundering by helping develop AML legislation and regulations, and by establishing 
the FIU in BOM. 
 
B.  Policy Framework and Actions 
50.  Policy reforms are presented in the policy matrix. The development policy letter (DPL) 
and policy matrix are in Appendix 4. The key measures are as follows: 
 
1.  Improve Efficiency and Stability of the Banking System 
a.  Improve the Collateral Framework 
51.  The  lack  of  a  well-functioning  collateral  framework  is  a  key  constraint  on  financial 
intermediation. In line with the FRGP’s recommendations, the Government recently enacted 
legislation to allow non-judicial foreclosure of collateral and to improve the information available 
from the property registration system. The introduction of non-judicial foreclosure procedures 
will help lower credit risk by facilitating debt recovery by banks. Improved collateral information 
will facilitate banks’ credit risk assessment. The FRGP calls for the strengthening of the PRO, 
which  will  be  responsible  for  implementing  the  non-judicial  procedures,  through  adequate 
training.  The  FRGP  also  supports  measures  to  improve  the  efficiency  of  document 
authentication for collateral registration to reduce the cost of notarizing documents. 
  
52.  The  effectiveness  of  the  collateral  framework  depends  not  only  on  the  design  and 
implementation of the laws and registry system, but also on public awareness about procedures 
and consequences of default. Therefore, the FRGP recommends that commercial banks be 
required to provide adequate information to potential borrowers before concluding collateral 
agreements.  
 
b.  Strengthen Corporate Governance 
53.  Improving  banks’  corporate  governance  to  ensure  financial  stability  and  depositor 
protection is one of the FRGP’s main objectives. Amending the Banking Law to require an 
independent  board  of  directors  is  fundamental  to  improving  commercial  banks’  corporate 
governance. A broader ownership structure will also help improve governance. Therefore, the 
FRGP recommends that the Banking Law be amended to allow commercial banks to be listed 
on the stock exchange so that the closely held ownership structure can be diversified. The 
FRGP calls for BOM to establish a working group comprising representatives from BOM and 
banks to develop a code of corporate governance to strengthen depositor protection. The code 
will  outline  principles  on  accountability  to,  and  safeguards  for,  the  public  and  to  principal 
stakeholders;  clearly  delineate  the  rights  and  responsibilities  of  the  board  and  senior 
management; provide for a professional and balanced board of directors with clearly specified 
fiduciary duties and safeguards against related-party transactions; and strengthen disclosure 
and reporting requirements. The FRGP also calls for the designation of a compliance officer to 
ensure banks’ compliance with laws and regulations.

14               
c.  Improve the Supervision of Banks’ Shareholders and Groups 
54.  To  monitor  and  mitigate  the  risks  arising  from  banks’  ownership  structure  and  the 
nonbank  financial  activities  of  affiliates  and  major  shareholders,  the  FRGP  calls  for  the 
formation  of  well-defined  formal  groups  by  adopting  the  financial  holding  company  (FHC) 
structure, rather than informal groups, which are difficult to supervise. The FRGP calls for the 
Government to amend the Banking Law to require a financial group that owns two or more 
banks, or banks and nonbank financial intermediaries to take the form of FHC. The FRGP will 
help develop the regulatory and supervisory framework for FHCs, including (i) consolidated 
financial reporting and disclosure, risk assessment, and supervision; and (ii) mechanisms to 
enhance coordination and information exchange among BOM and other financial regulators. 
The FRGP calls for the improved regulation on the definitions, limitations, and reporting and 
disclosure of related-party transactions to strengthen the BOM’s monitoring of related-party 
transactions. Establishment of FHCs will also help develop the NBF sector by allowing qualified 
banks to engage in a wider range of financial activities (including brokering/dealing, underwriting 
and managing investment funds) through affiliates and subsidiaries under the FHC structure. 
 
2.  Enhance the Role of the NBF Sector in Financial Intermediation 
a.  Improve Regulatory and Supervisory Structure 
55.  NBF regulation is weak and fragmented. The individual NBF regulators do not have the 
resources and expertise to effectively oversee the insurance sector and the securities market. 
Likewise, BOM’s regulatory resources are focused primarily on the banking sector. There is a 
strong rationale for establishing a single NBFRC for NBFIs, SCCs, insurance, and the securities 
market. Specifically, an integrated framework will improve efficiency by allowing for the sharing 
of  infrastructure  and  human  resources  such  as  administrative  and  personnel  services,  IT 
specialist, chief accountant, and chief enforcement officer. The cost saving from consolidation 
could then be used to improve the quality of supervision by upgrading and maintaining IT-MIS; 
building capacity of existing staff; and recruiting more specialized experts in the areas of credit 
cooperatives, the securities market, and insurance. An integrated agency will increase the 
chances of attracting and retaining qualified staff by offering more varied and challenging career 
paths.  More  important,  having  a  single  regulator  with  an  explicit  mandate  to  promote  the 
development of NBF sector and to protect investors will improve accountability and enhance 
investor awareness and confidence in the sector. Having a larger pool of staff will facilitate the 
switching of regulatory staff from one subsector to another in the event of significant market 
turbulence. For instance, should there be a catastrophic event that had a large impact on the 
insurance sector, NBRFC would be able to temporarily deploy additional staff to this subsector.  
 
56.  While Mongolia could adopt a fully integrated financial services authority over the long 
term, NBRFC is a more appropriate structure in the medium-term. There is a significant gap in 
the  level  of  development  between  the  banking  and  NBF  sectors,  as  well  as  between  the 
capacity of BOM and of MSEC and ISU. Gradual consolidation is important to facilitate smooth 
transition and to ensure that bank supervision is not compromised. Once a core group of 
qualified regulators has been developed within NBFRC, the Government can decide to merge 
bank and NBF sector regulation under a single regulator.  
 
57.  The  FRGP  supports  the  establishment  of  NBFRC,  which  will  be  responsible  for 
regulating and supervising the NBFIs, insurance companies, SCCs, and the securities market 
and  intermediaries.  This  will  entail  (i)  developing  the  legal  basis  for  establishing  a  more 
independent, accountable, and transparent regulator; (ii) preparing a time-sequenced action

15 
plan for the start-up of NBFRC, including identification of budget and staffing requirements; and 
(iii) developing mechanisms for effective coordination between MOF, BOM, and NBFRC to 
facilitate policy coordination and harmonization of regulation and enforcement of applicable laws 
and regulations. To enable NBFRC to better manage financial sector risks, and more generally 
to meet its mandate of promoting financial sector stability and development, the FRGP calls for 
the establishment of adequate IT equipment in NBFRC. 
 
58.  The FRGP incorporates measures to strengthen MSE. It recommends that MSE develop 
a  plan  for  self-regulation  identifying  MSE’s  functions,  and  clearly  distinguishing  between 
MSEC’s and MSE’s roles. In line with the Government’s medium-term objective, the FRGP will 
help prepare MSE for divestiture by developing a medium-term strategy to improve revenue and 
operational capacity.  
 
b.  Strengthen the Legal and Regulatory Framework  
59.  A clear and comprehensive legal basis is fundamental for the effective regulation and 
supervision of the financial sector. The FRGP recommends a number of revisions to the Law on 
Securities Market to address the weaknesses identified above. Specifically, the amended law 
should (i) clearly distinguish between the provisions that apply to public and to private offers, (ii) 
clarify that joint stock companies are not required to be listed on MSE, (iii) strengthen the 
obligations of the governing persons of investment funds and fund management companies, (iv) 
introduce  “fit  and  proper”  requirement  for  the  governing  persons  of  securities  issuers  and 
professional participants, and (v) clearly state that it is an offense for an individual or an entity to 
conduct the business of a securities market intermediary without obtaining license from MSEC. 
 
60.  The FRGP will help develop regulatory framework for the insurance sector. Specifically, 
the FRGP recommends that the Government issue regulations that include licensing, prudential 
and reporting requirements for insurance companies. 
 
61.  The FRGP recommends that the Government amend the Law on Cooperatives to clearly 
define membership requirements, authorized business activities, supervision, sanctions, and 
authorized methods to terminate SCC activities. In view of the scarcity of regulatory resources 
and the growing number of SCCs, the FRGP calls for the introduction of appropriate licensing 
requirements to check excessive growth in the number of SCCs. The FRGP recommends that 
NBFRC use a risk-based approach concentrating on the larger and potential “problem” SCCs. 
For instance, the frequency of on-site inspections could be based on the size of the SCC and 
the risk assessment from on-site and off-site inspections. 
 
c.  Enhance Investor Confidence by Strengthening Governance and 
Transparency  
62.  While investor confidence in the financial sector is generally weak, it is particularly low in 
the case of the capital market. Confidence in the equity market was seriously undermined in the 
late 1990s when over 300,000 investors lost close to MNT1 billion because of the collapse of 
the two custodian banks holding clearing funds of equity investors. In January 2002, the cabinet 
instructed MOF and the State Property Committee to use a portion of the proceeds from 
privatization of a number SOEs to compensate investors. However, so far only 3,500 investors 
have received a total of MNT347 million in compensation. To help restore investor confidence, 
the FRGP calls for the compensation of all eligible investors.

16               
63.  The FRGP calls for NBFRC to require regulated entities, including insurance companies, 
NBFIs, and securities market participants to appoint at least two independent directors and one 
designated  compliance  officer.  The  FRGP  calls  for  the  establishment  of  “fit  and  proper” 
standards  for  officers  and  directors  of  regulated  entities,  whereby  NBFRC  will  be  able  to 
prescribe,  and  review  the  qualification  of,  appointed  or elected  officers  and  directors.  The 
compliance  officer  will  be  primarily  responsible  for  stakeholder  protection  by  detecting, 
preventing,  and  resolving  problems  before  they  become  rule  violations.  The  FRGP  thus 
recommends that NBFRC, in coordination with BOM, develop and administer a training and 
certification program.  
 
64.  Amending the Company Law will be crucial for enhancing corporate governance and 
investor protection. The main amendments proposed include (i) limiting the total number of 
founding and non-founding members of a limited liability company to 50; and (ii) creating a new 
category of “public company”, which will include (a) a joint stock company, (b) a limited liability 
company licensed by BOM or NBFRC, and (c) a limited liability company that has access to 
public  funds  by  offering  debt  securities.  The  first  amendment  will  prevent  limited  liability 
companies, which are subject to lower standards of governance, from accessing funds from the 
public. The second amendment captures financial institutions and companies that have access 
to funds from the public, which can then be subject to higher standards of corporate governance 
and disclosure. For instance, public companies will be required to have a board of directors with 
well-defined roles and responsibilities. Public companies will also be required to submit to MSE 
and/or  the  supervisor  their  annual  reports,  including  audited  financial  statements  and 
governance practices.  
 
65.  To  promote  transparency  based  on  disclosure  of  reliable,  relevant,  and  timely 
information, the FRGP recommends that NBFRC, MSE, and BOM gradually publish through 
their website the annual audited financial statements of all public companies. 
 
d.  Remove Tax Impediments 
66.  In  line  with  the  FRGP  recommendation,  the  Government  recently  submitted  to 
Parliament  draft  amendments  to  the  CIT  Law.  The  draft  amendments  aim  to  reduce  the 
distortion created by the two-tier tax structure, which is biased against large firms and thereby 
impedes capital market development. Specifically, the amendments will increase the threshold 
for the 30% tax bracket from the current level of MNT100 million to MNT500 million, reducing 
the disincentives for companies to grow. The Government views this as an intermediate step 
toward introducing a single corporate tax rate over the long term. The amendments also aim to 
harmonize  the  provisions  for  probable  losses  between  banks  and  nonbank  financial 
intermediaries, and to make insurance premiums paid by legal entities during ordinary course of 
business tax-deductible.  
 
67.  However, the draft amendments do not fully harmonize the tax treatment of returns on 
different types of financial assets, not only discouraging public investment in stocks but also the 
listing of companies. Therefore, the FRGP recommends harmonizing the taxation of interest 
income on bank deposits and corporate bonds, and dividends and capital gains from equity 
investment.  
 
3.  Establish an Effective Anti-Money-Laundering Regime  
68.  As a first step toward establishing an effective AML regime, the Government has drafted 
an AML law. The draft law is being finalized for submission to Parliament. Once the AML

17 
legislation is in place, appropriate regulatory and institutional arrangements will have to be 
established and institutional capacity built to effectively implement the law. The FRGP calls for 
the development of the legal and regulatory framework, and the establishment of an FIU in BOM 
as the lead AML agency. Establishing the FIU will entail the adoption of rules and regulations 
under the AML law, approval of structure and appointment of key staff, and development of the 
IT system for monitoring and reporting suspicious financial transactions. Besides training the 
FIU staff, the FRGP also recommends that BOM train financial institutions in compliance with 
the AML law and regulations, and relevant agencies in the investigation and prosecution of 
money laundering. 
 
69.  Coordination among all related entities is essential for the AML system to be effective. 
The FRGP calls for the establishment of a national coordinating committee (NCC) comprising 
BOM, MOF, the Ministry of Justice and Home Affairs (MOJ), the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the 
police, and NBFRC. The FRGP also recommends forming a financial sector liaison committee 
(FSLC)  representing  relevant  government  agencies  and  compliance  officers  of  financial 
institutions. The FSLC will provide a framework for coordination and consultation between 
government agencies and the financial sector. 
 
C.  Important Features 
70.  The FRGP aims to address legal, regulatory, institutional, and policy constraints on 
financial sector development. The FRGP will enhance the efficiency of financial intermediation 
by  developing  a  broad-based  financial  system  with  alternative  channels  for  resource 
mobilization and allocation. This will, in turn, promote economic growth and create jobs. The 
development of a robust and broad-based financial system will reduce the likelihood of financial 
crises that could wipe out savings and have adverse macroeconomic consequences such as 
higher inflation and tax rates. The FRGP is designed as a continuation the FSPL II, and will 
build on the achievements of the FSPL I and II. The reforms proposed under the FRGP are fully 
in line with the Government’s priorities and medium-term objectives. 
 
D.  Financing Plan 
71.  It is proposed that ADB support the Government’s policy reforms by providing a loan of 
SDR6,917,000 ($10 million). The Borrower will be Mongolia. The loan will be from the ADB’s 
Special Funds resources. The loan will have a term of 24 years, including a grace period of 8 
years, and an interest charge of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per year for 
the remaining period. The loan proceeds are expected to be used over a period of 48 months 
from the date of effectiveness.

costs resulting from the FRGP. The adjustment costs are not easily quantifiable, but the direct 
and more obvious adjustment costs amount to about $19.5 million, including the following:

economies of scale and improved efficiency in the long run, it will entail certain 
costs in the short to medium term. This will include mainly costs of recruiting 
specialized experts, training existing staff, developing and issuing guidelines and 
procedures, and establishing IT-MIS. Estimated cost: $4 million. 
(ii)  Collateral  framework.  Once  the  legislation  on  non-judicial  foreclosure  is  in

the  PRO  and  commercial  bank  staff  in  the  new  procedures  for  non-judicial

VI.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Benefits 
92.  The FRGP will promote financial system stability and enhance economic growth through 
efficient resource mobilization and allocation. The collateral reforms will help reduce the cost of 
borrowing and increase access to credit. The measures to improve corporate governance in 
banks will enhance depositor protection. The increased role of the NBF sector in financial 
intermediation  will  reduce  the  risks  associated  with  over-reliance  on  the  banking  system. 
Increased  competition  from  alternative  sources  of  financial  intermediation  will  enhance 
efficiency, and the financial system as a whole will become more resilient to exogenous shocks. 
Firms will be able to diversify their source of capital and have access to long-term funds for 
productive investment.  
 
93.  By increasing access to credit, savings instruments, and insurance products, the FRGP 
will help protect the poor from income disruptions and enable them to meet unanticipated 
expenditures. The development of viable SCCs will enhance financial sector outreach to the 
vulnerable and the poor. AML reforms will help enhance investor protection and confidence and 
financial stability by minimizing the scope for money laundering through the financial system. 
The summary of poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 8. 
 
94.  Specific benefits can be outlined as follows:  
 
(i)  Adopting  procedures  for  non-judicial  foreclosure  will  reduce  credit  risk. 
Strengthening the PRO and improving document authentication procedures will 
reduce the cost of collateral registration. These measures will reduce the cost of 
borrowing and improve access to credit. 
(ii)  By  introducing  legal  and  regulatory  measures  to  improve  governance  in 
commercial banks, the FRGP will help ensure depositor protection. Depositor 
protection  will  also  be  enhanced  by  improving  supervision  of  groups  and 
conglomerates that control financial institutions. 
(iii)  The FRGP will help develop the legal and regulatory framework for the NBF 
sector, including NBFIs, the insurance sector, the capital market, and SCCs. This 
will increase access to long-term funding, and savings and insurance products. 
By helping establish an effective regulator for the NBF sector, the FRGP will help 
ensure that the sector is adequately supervised and the laws and regulations 
enforced, thereby enhancing investor protection. 
(iv)  The Government’s adherence to its policy—as announced through the 2001 
parliament  resolution—of  compensating  investors  who  suffered  losses  in  the

22               
equity market in the late 1990s will help restore investor confidence and generate 
investment in the capital markets. 
(v)  Investor  confidence  will  be  boosted  by  measures  to  improve  disclosure  by 
financial  institutions  and  securities  issuers.  By  improving  the  accuracy  and 
timeliness  of  financial  statements,  the  FRGP  will  enable  investors  to  better 
assess the potential risks and rewards of their investments. 
(vi)  By reducing the distortions created by the two-tier corporate tax system, the 
FRGP  will  promote  corporate  sector  and  capital  market  development. 
Harmonizing  the  tax  treatment  of  returns  on  different  types  of  financial 
investment will help develop a more balanced and resilient financial system. 
(vii)  An effective AML system will strengthen investor confidence in general and in the 
financial  sector  in  particular,  as  money  laundering  generally  stems  from 
corruption and other criminal activities.  
 
B.  Risks and Safeguards 
95.  Poor management of the transition to NBFRC is a key risk. A number of measures have 
been taken to facilitate timely and orderly transition. An overall strategy and a detailed time-
bound action plan have been prepared in close consultation with the Government and other 
stakeholders.  During  program  preparation,18  considerable  efforts  were  made  to  reach  a 
common understanding and consensus among different government agencies on the objectives 
and the structure of NBFRC. BOM has committed to transfer at least eight qualified staff 
members to NBFRC, and the Government has agreed to allocate budget to ensure an adequate 
pool  of  qualified  professional  staff  to  conduct  regulatory,  supervisory,  and  enforcement

A.  Banking Sector 
1.  Background 
1.  Mongolia  moved  from  a  Soviet-style  monobanking  system  to  a  two-tiered  banking 
system  in  1991.  However,  numerous  nonperforming  loans  (NPLs)  were  inherited  from  the 
monobanking  system.  Continued  directed  lending  to  poorly  performing  enterprises  further 
damaged the solvency and stability of the banking system. In 1996, four of the five largest 
banks could not meet the liquidity ratio of 20% set by the Bank of Mongolia (BOM). Two major 
banks  were  closed  in  1996  and  their  assets  were  transferred  to  the  newly  established 
Reconstruction Bank. Reconstruction Bank and another major bank were closed down in 1999, 
while another major bank (Agriculture Bank) was placed under receivership and subsequently 
rehabilitated. Some small banks were also liquidated during the late 1990s. Over the past 
decade, banking laws and regulations have been strengthened; the Government’s involvement 
in bank operations has been substantially reduced; and a well-functioning interbank market has 
been introduced. As a result, public confidence in the banking sector has been strengthened 
and the sector has grown rapidly over the past few years. 
 
2.  Mongolia has 17 banks, of which 1 is fully state-owned, 2 have state participation, and 
14 are private. All the banks are limited liability companies with a small number of shareholders 
(1–4) controlling majority of shares. The 17 banks have a total of 684 branches and offices, of 
which around 500 are outside Ulaanbaatar. The sector is highly concentrated, with the four 
largest banks accounting for 61% of total banking assets and 69% of deposits. Each of the 
seven smallest banks has assets of less than MNT20 billion. BOM will increase minimum capital 
requirements of banks from the current MNT4 billion to MNT8 billion in 2006. Since 10 of the 17 
banks have capital levels under MNT5 billion, and only 31 have capital levels exceeding MNT8 
billion, the increase in the minimum capital requirement is expected to lead to consolidation 
within the banking sector. 
 
2.  Regulation and Supervision 
3.  The Banking Law, enacted in 1996 and amended a number of times since, provides the 
legal basis for BOM to regulate and supervise the banking sector. About 40 staff members are 
in charge of supervising 17 banks. BOM has made substantial progress in strengthening its 
regulatory  capacities  in  recent  years.  The  International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF)  has  been 
supporting BOM in establishing and upgrading various regulations.  
 
4.  The  loan  classification  and  loan  loss  provisioning  standards  are  simple  and 
conservative, and are well implemented. The classification criteria consist of quantitative criteria 
based on the duration of loan overdue and qualitative criteria based on the conditions of 
borrowers.  To  minimize  discretion,  the  qualitative  criteria  are  only  used  to  downgrade  the 
classification derived from quantitative criteria and are mainly based on numerical indicators 
such as return on assets2 and capital–asset ratio. The amount of loan loss provisioning is 
determined according to the classification under the BOM guidelines (e.g., 1% for performing, 
5% for past due). The required provisioning rates for substandard and doubtful loans were 
increased by the amendment of the guidelines (25–40% for substandard, and 50–75% for 
doubtful) in 2004. Commercial banks submit loan classification reports monthly to BOM.

7.  Banks’ financial conditions have improved considerably since the late 1990s. The total

banking sector as a whole has been profitable for the past 5 years (2000–2004).  
 
8.  Despite significant improvements in financial conditions, rapid credit expansion since

outstanding loan amount increased from MNT67 billion at the end of 2000 to MNT635 billion at

whereas credit grew by 44% in 2004. The NPL ratio showed an upturn from 7% in 2002 to 8% in
