internal controls in banks is a main reason for weak loan performance. Even the top banks have 
not established up-to-standard internal credit rating systems. Certain banks are believed to lend 
significant amounts to those close to bank management and shareholders at below-market 
rates, and without considering the borrowers’ creditworthiness. The gap between the actual 
interest income of banks and the interest income calculated from the reported interest rates is 
one indication of the widespread use of such preferred interest rates.  
 
9.  Another  concern  regarding  the  banks’  financial  conditions  is  declining  profitability. 
Although the net profit (after tax) of the entire banking sector has increased from MNT8.8 billion 
in 2001 to MNT17.3 billion in 2004, return on assets has declined from 3.9% in 2000 to 1.6% in 
2004. One of the reasons for the declining profitability is the increased loan loss provisioning 
caused by the deterioration of asset quality and application of stricter provisioning standards. 
The narrowing interest rate margin and slow increase of fee income are also important factors.

B.  Nonbank Financial Institutions (NBFIs) 
1.  Background 
10.  In Mongolia, the term NBFI refers to a licensee under the Law on Nonbank Financial 
Activities (2002). The activities covered under this law include lending, factoring, leasing, issuing 
guarantees, issuing payment instruments, electronic payments and remittance services, foreign 
exchange services, trust services, investment in short-term financial instruments, and advisory 
services. NBFIs are not allowed to take deposits. The number, loans, and total assets of NBFIs 
have grown rapidly since 2000, when Mongol Credit was established as the first licensed NBFI. 
Of the 114 NBFIs registered in 2004, 9 were foreign-owned or joint ventures. Most of the NBFIs 
provide small consumer loans or short-term loans to small and medium-sized enterprises, and a 
handful are engaged in other activities such as leasing and foreign exchange trading. NBFIs are 
incorporated as limited liability companies, and are typically owned by a single individual, a 
family, or a small group of related individuals. With total assets of MNT28.7 billion, NBFIs as a 
group account for about 2.6% of banking sector assets.

2.  Regulation and Supervision 
11.  The Law on Nonbank Financial Activities provides the legal basis for regulation and 
supervision of NBFIs. It authorizes BOM to license entities to carry out nonbank financial 
activities, to issue regulations and procedures and to supervise and monitor the activities of 
NBFIs. Each NBFI is licensed for one or more activities, but there is no overall license to be an 
NBFI. The penalty provisions of the law also empower BOM to confiscate illegally generated 
income and impose fines 5–20 times the minimum salary for individuals and 20–40 times the 
minimum salary for NBFIs for breaches of the laws. The minimum capital requirements for 
NBFIs are based on location: the minimum  capital required for the NBFIs incorporated in 
Ulaanbaatar is MNT100 million, for NBFIs in Darkhan and Erdenet MNT30 million, and for 
NBFIs in rural areas MNT10 million. NBFIs are subject to a five-class asset classification system 
and provisioning standards similar to those for banks. BOM conducts on-site inspections for 
NBFIs and issues specific orders or revokes license if serious breaches are found. In 2003, five 
NBFI licenses were revoked. BOM has about 10 member-staff in its NBFI division, which is 
responsible for supervising NBFIs and savings and credit cooperatives (SCCs). 
 
3.  Financial Conditions and Operations 
12.  Compared with other nonbank financial intermediaries in Mongolia, NBFIs under the Law 
on Nonbank Financial Activities are well regulated and operate in a stable manner. The asset 
quality and earnings of the entire sector appear fair and the NPL ratio has declined in recent 
years. While most of the smaller NBFIs are financed by equity, some large ones have significant 
loan financing and accrued interests. Total liabilities in the sector amount to 30% of sector 
assets.

14.  SCCs  are  governed  by  the  Law  on  Cooperatives,  which  also  governs  agriculture, 
manufacturing,  and  consumer  cooperatives.  The  law  does  not  provide  adequate  basis  to 
regulate deposit-taking and lending activities of cooperatives. Although the law sets out the 
limitations  on  SCCs’  activities,  rights,  and  obligations  of  members,  and  obligations  of 
management and other governance requirements, it does not assign any government agency to 
supervise the activities of SCCs and monitor their compliance with the law. SCCs that take 
deposits and make loans are not required to obtain a license from a regulator, though SCCs are 
registered with the General Department of National Taxation (GDNT). While the amendments to 
the law in 2002 provided for prudential standards for SCCs issued by BOM, the law does not 
provide BOM with powers to effectively supervise SCCs, such as on-site inspections, reporting 
requirements, suspension of business, and revocation of registration.  
 
15.  An SCC interim supervision unit was established under GDNT to supervise SCCs from 
June 2003 to June 2004. In accordance with a parliament resolution, GDNT and BOM jointly 
conducted inspections of all the active SCCs for the first time during the first quarter of 2004. In 
April 2004, SCC supervision was transferred to BOM, also on an interim basis. Although BOM is 
designated as the supervisor of SCCs, no BOM staff member is specifically tasked to supervise 
SCCs full-time. The interim supervisory assignment with limited legal power and staff resources 
makes it difficult for BOM to take on the full responsibility of supervising SCCs. 
 
3.  Financial Conditions and Operations 
16.  The joint inspections of SCCs by GDNT and BOM uncovered many serious problems. 
Although SCCs are allowed to take deposits only from the members, many SCCs are taking 
deposits  from  the  public  and  therefore  operating  as  banks.  Most  SCCs  are  found  to  be 
improperly recruiting members4 and exceeding BOM’s loan limit to a single borrower. The 
deposit interest rate was 1.85–4.00% per month, far higher than that of commercial banks, and 
lending interest rates were 2.7–8.0% per month. About half of the registered SCCs (288 out of 
570) were reported to be either inactive, liquidated, or could not be located by the authorities. 
Some SCCs were found to be collecting deposits to finance election campaigns of politicians 
and some are believed to be pyramiding schemes.

and protection of fund assets and the governance obligations of the governing persons of 
investment companies and funds management companies. 
 
3.  Financial Conditions and Operations 
25.  Most of the securities companies are small and lack capacity. In 2004, 19 of the 25 
broker/dealer  companies  executed  stock  purchases  and  sales  of  less  than  MNT50  million 
(minimum capital requirement for a broker/dealer company) and 8 companies less than MNT10 
million. Most of the brokers rely on income from sales of the government bonds through MSE 
and business activities unrelated to the securities business. Most brokers are not engaged in 
the securities business on a full time basis. Anecdotal evidence suggests that some securities 
brokers are trading their customers’ securities without consent of the customers. 
 
F.  Insurance Companies 
1.  Background 
26.  Until 1991, there was only one  state-owned insurance company operating—Mongol 
Daatgal. In 1991, another state-owned insurance company, Tushig Daatgal, was established to 
specialize in agriculture. The first private insurance company, Ard Daatgal, was established in 
1994. Since then, the insurance sector has grown rapidly. The number of insurance companies 
has increased to 23 in 2004, and both former state-owned insurance companies have been 
privatized. The amount of premiums collected by insurance companies has increased from 
MNT3.0 billion in 1998 to MNT6.3 billion in 2003. Nevertheless, the sector remains small with 
total insurance premium amounting to only 0.5% of GDP. The sector is highly concentrated with 
Mongol Daatgal accounting for 74% of total insurance sector premiums in 2003. Aircraft related 
(hull and liability) insurance comprises the largest category of insurance and accounted for 40% 
of the industry. The only class of mandatory insurance is motor vehicle liability, accounting for 
8%  of  total  industry  premium.  Combined  with  property  insurance  for  motor  vehicle,  motor 
vehicle  related  insurance  accounted  for  20%  of  the  industry.  Property  casualty  insurance 
accounted for 15% and the personal accident, disability, and travel insurance in total accounted 
for about 10%. Mongolian insurance companies do not offer life insurance products. 
 
2.  Regulation and Supervision 
27.  Mongolia’s first  Law  on  Insurance  was  enacted  in  1998.  This  law  provided  for  the 
Ministry of Finance (MOF) to license insurance companies and issue regulations. However, the 
law designated another agency—Insurance Supervisory Unit (ISU) under the State Agency for 
Professional Inspectors—to make recommendations to MOF regarding license applications and 
supervise insurance companies’ compliance with laws and the terms of their licenses. The new 
insurance  laws  (Law  on  Insurance  and  Law  on  Licensing  and  Supervision  of  Insurance 
Intermediaries), prepared with Asian Development Bank (ADB) support, were enacted in 2004.

The new laws designate the to-be-established nonbank regulatory agency to supervise the 
sector, including through licensing, compliance monitoring, investigations, enforcement, and 
issuing  regulations.  ISU  has  only  seven  staff  members,  none  of  whom  have  specialized 
expertise in insurance.  
 
3.  Financial Conditions and Operations 
28.  There are 23 insurance companies in a market of only MNT6.3 billion, with one dominant 
company accounting for 74%. Since most insurance companies are small, they are especially 
vulnerable to shocks from large claims. Two insurance companies have gone bankrupt during 
the past 18 months. The amount of insurance premium paid by an individual for a motor vehicle 
liability insurance or a personal accident insurance is typically as low as $2–3 equivalent. It is 
unlikely that the cost of a traffic accident can be covered by insurance claim payments under 
such a low level of insurance premiums. 
 
29.  The payout ratio (claims paid as a percentage of total premiums collected) is low at 
about 20%. The low payout ratio is largely due to the reluctance of some insurers to pay claims 
owed to policy holders. In 2003, only two insurance companies recorded a payout ratio higher 
than 25% (102% and 44%), one of which went bankrupt. The total operating expense of the 
entire sector was MNT2.1 billion (57% of the net premium income, i.e., insurance premium 
collected minus reinsurance premium paid). Seven of the 21 companies made losses in 2003 
and the net profit/loss after tax of the entire sector was negative in 2003.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Mongolia: 
The financial sector contributes to poverty reduction through its pivotal role in facilitating sustainable economic growth. 
By mobilizing savings and channeling them to productive investment in the real sector, the financial sector promotes 
economic growth and creates jobs, thereby reducing poverty. The financial sector also directly helps to reduce 
poverty. By increasing access to credit, an efficient financial sector enables the poor to engage in income-generating 
activities. By increasing access to savings and insurance products, an a broad-based financial system also helps 
safeguard the poor and the vulnerable segments of the population from negative shocks to their incomes and enables 
them to meet unanticipated expenditure needs.  
 
Low-income households are most vulnerable to the loss of savings from banking crises. The poor are also especially 
vulnerable to the adverse consequences of financial crises such as job loss caused by increased bankruptcies, as well 
as higher taxes and inflation and lower social expenditures. A well-governed financial sector reduces the likelihood 
and severity of financial crises, and provides safeguard against a corresponding increase in poverty incidence.  
 
The country strategy and program for Mongolia identifies underdevelopment of the financial sector as a cause of 
poverty. The cost of borrowing in Mongolia is high, and financial outreach is limited. Bank lending is predominantly 
collateral-based, and low-income households are particularly affected by the high cost of collateral registration. The 
lack of long-term funds limits investment and constrains economic growth. There are few savings instruments and 
insurance products. Poor governance practices undermine the stability of the financial system and investor protection. 
Addressing these weaknesses to develop an efficient, well-balanced, and well-governed financial system will be 
crucial for reducing the cost of borrowing, increasing investment, and creating jobs.  
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
In 2003, the Government finalized a national poverty reduction strategy in the form of the Economic Growth Support 
and Poverty Reduction Strategy, from which the new Government derived a new law outlining the National Action Plan 
for 2004–2008. Two components are particularly prominent in the Government’s strategy: higher, stable private 
sector-led growth aimed at improving living standards and reducing income disparities; and social development aimed 
at improving income opportunities and the quality of public services and accessibility for the poor. The strategy 
outlines financial sector priorities to support growth, including the development of long-term lending and diverse 
financial  services,  lower  interest  rates,  and  wider  access  to  credit.  Toward  its  social  development  goal,  the 
Government intends to create jobs and income opportunities through investment in education and private sector 
development. The Financial Regulation and Governance Program (FRGP) is fully consistent with the Government’s 
medium-term objective of promoting private sector-led growth. 
 
The FRGP supports the strengthening of corporate governance in banks and the improvement of the collateral 
framework. Poor governance in banks could undermine depositor protection, and jeopardize the savings of low-
income households. By introducing legal and regulatory measures to improve internal controls in commercial banks, 
the FRGP will contribute toward mitigating such risks and ensuring depositor protection. By lowering the (perceived) 
risk of lending and the cost of collateral registration, improved collateral framework will help reduce the cost of 
borrowing and facilitate access to credit by the poor. 
 
The FRGP supports the development of the nonbank financial sector, including capital markets, insurance sector, 
nonbank financial institutions (NBFIs) and savings and credit cooperatives (SCCs). The FRGP will promote capital 
market  development  by  strengthening  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework  and  strengthening  governance  and 
disclosure to protect investors. Capital market development will support long-term economic growth and employment 
creation by facilitating resource mobilization and investment. Further, capital market development will help lower the 
cost of borrowing by creating alternatives to bank loans. This will improve the poor’s access to credit.

NBFIs and SCCs typically provide small loans and other financial services to households and employment-generating
